pending_diagnosis: DIAGNOSIS: Fatal Familial Insomnia (FFI) THE SMOKING GUN: The key clue, confirmed via sequencing of the peripheral blood mononuclear cells, was the identification of the D178N point mutation on the PRNP (prion protein) gene, coupled with methionine homozygosity at codon 129. This genetic profile is pathognomonic for the inherited form of this rare transmissible spongiform encephalopathy. A focused family history review revealed several elderly relatives who had died rapidly following a syndrome of psychiatric disturbance and gait instability, previously misdiagnosed as rapid-onset dementia or encephalitis. PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: Fatal Familial Insomnia is one of the human prion diseases. It is caused by the misfolding of the normal prion protein (PrP) into an abnormal, pathogenic conformation (PrP). This misfolded protein is resistant to degradation and accumulates, acting as a template to convert more normal proteins into the misfolded form. In FFI, the abnormal PrP aggregates specifically target and destroy neurons primarily in the thalamus, particularly the ventral medial and anterior thalamic nuclei. These nuclei are critical regulators of the sleep-wake cycle and autonomic stability. The selective destruction of these central regulatory centers results in the hallmark clinical triad observed in this patient: 1. Intractable, untreatable insomnia (agrypnia). 2. Severe dysautonomia (tachycardia, hyperhidrosis, hyperthermia). 3. Rapidly progressive motor signs (ataxia and pyramidal signs) and dementia.
